user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_irq_init:
```c
int metal_linux_irq_init(void)
{
	int ret;

	memset(&irqs, 0, sizeof(irqs));

	irq_notify_fd = eventfd(0, EFD_CLOEXEC);
	if (irq_notify_fd < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR,
			  "Failed to create eventfd for IRQ handling.\n");
		return  -EAGAIN;
	}

	metal_mutex_init(&irq_lock);
	irq_handling_stop = false;
	ret = metal_irq_register_controller(&linux_irq_cntr);
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR,
			  "Linux IRQ controller failed to register.\n");
		return -EINVAL;
	}
	ret = pthread_create(&irq_pthread, NULL,
			     metal_linux_irq_handling, NULL);
	if (ret != 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "Failed to create IRQ thread: %d.\n",
			  ret);
		return -EAGAIN;
	}

	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_linux_irq_init:
static struct metal_irq irqs[MAX_IRQS]
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Only the call to memset is relevant to MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 because that rule applies to functions from <string.h>. No other string.h functions (e.g. memcpy, memmove, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, memcmp, memset beyond the cited call) are present in the shown function. The remaining statements do not invoke <string.h> APIs and therefore do not fall under Rule 21.17: eventfd(), metal_log(), metal_mutex_init(), metal_irq_register_controller(), pthread_create(), and the assignments to irq_handling_stop/irq_notify_fd are not string handling calls. The provided additional symbol definition (static struct metal_irq irqs[MAX_IRQS]) identifies the object targeted by the memset; no other uses of string.h functions appear in the supplied code fragment or related symbols.
